Notes: Schools reopened in September, but schedules have been modified. Classes are now shorter (30-45 min) and larger classes have been split into two sessions.   Teachers at pre-university education level are required to be either vaccinated or show a weekly Covid test certificate  Lecturers and university students are required to be either vaccinated or show a weekly Covid test certificate  Social distancing measures, emphasis on hygiene, and mask-wearing  School year started 2 weeks earlier to allow for repetition of classes for missed content   âVia a video message on Sunday, Minister of Education, Sports and Youth Evis Kushi wished all students and teachers a new successful school year and urged everyone "to respect anti-COVID measures as health is the most important element in these pandemic times."â    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211113141838/http://www.news.cn/english/europe/2021-09/28/c_1310214789.htm

Nationwide measures  "the Corona Commission will determine the epidemiological risk for the educational institutions per federal state. On the basis of this classification, the Education Directorate determines the risk level for the federal state in agreement with the central office by ordinance. The responsible education directorate then informs the schools. Defined framework conditions also enable flexible measures to be taken at the school location."    Corona traffic light map  "On October 21, 2021, the Corona Commission classifies all of Austria as high risk. The federal states of Carinthia, Styria, Tyrol, Vorarlberg and Vienna are also rated as having a high risk. Burgenland is rated with medium risk. Lower Austria, Upper Austria and Salzburg are classified as very high risk.    "The classification for the education sector is still risk level I for Vorarlberg and risk level II for all other federal states. "    Sources:  https://archive.vn/3dN2m [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/rc1ij [Corona traffic light map]  https://archive.vn/ZM5VV [Coronavirus - Current Measures]

Nationwide measures  From week 38, the Corona Commission will determine the epidemiological risk for the educational institutions per federal state. On the basis of this classification, the Education Directorate determines the risk level for the federal state in agreement with the central office by ordinance. The responsible education directorate then informs the schools. Defined framework conditions also enable flexible measures to be taken at the school location.     Corona traffic light map  On October 28, 2021, the Corona Commission classifies all of Austria as very high risk. The federal states of Carinthia, Lower Austria, Upper Austria, Salzburg, Styria, Tyrol and Vorarlberg are also rated as having a very high risk. The federal states of Burgenland and Vienna are rated as high risk.   The classification for the education sector is risk level II for all federal states.     Sources:  https://archive.vn/2WOM0 - Corona traffic light map  https://archive.vn/vgVms - Nationwide Measures  https://archive.vn/nmP8T - Current Measures

Nationwide measures  From week 38, the Corona Commission will determine the epidemiological risk for the educational institutions per federal state. On the basis of this classification, the Education Directorate determines the risk level for the federal state in agreement with the central office by ordinance. The responsible education directorate then informs the schools. Defined framework conditions also enable flexible measures to be taken at the school location. The classification for the education sector is risk level II for all federal states. At work   â¢  Workplaces may only be entered by teachers who are in direct contact with students, owners, operators and employees with direct customer contact, persons who are active in dealing with parties in administrative authorities and administrative courts if they are in contact with students, with customers and with parties wear a mask in closed rooms unless the risk of infection is minimized by other suitable protective measures.   â¢  The obligation to wear a mask does not apply if the persons present a 3-G certificate.   â¢  The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.   â¢  By agreement between employers and employees, stricter rules for wearing a mask, an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard can be made in addition to the arrangements made for wearing a mask.    Customer areas   â¢  An FFP2 mask must be worn in everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and in grocery stores.    â¢  When entering and driving in other customer areas as well as the connecting structures of structurally connected operating facilities (e.g. shopping centers, market halls), customers who have not been vaccinated or have recovered must wear an FFP2 mask.   â¢  The operator of business premises for the use of body-friendly services may only let in customers if they can present 3-G evidence. The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    3-G rule  The 3-G rule applies in the following areas:     â¢  gastronomy   â¢  Body-hugging services   â¢  Hotel and lodging   â¢  Leisure facilities (e.g. dance schools, zoos)   â¢  Cultural establishments    â¢  Non-public sports facilities   â¢  Meetings (from a number of participants of more than 100 people)   â¢  Trade and consumer fairs, congresses   â¢  Coaches and excursion boats    In addition, the 3G rule continues to apply in the following areas and for the following people:    In the provision of mobile care and support services   â¢  For visitors and employees of retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled   â¢  For residents for new admission in old people's and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled   â¢  For visitors and employees of hospitals or health resorts   â¢  For employees from other locations where health services are provided.    The following applies as evidence of a low epidemiological risk:   â¢  Evidence of negative testing for SARS-CoV-2   â¢  Medical confirmation of a past infection   â¢  Separation notice   â¢  Vaccination certificate   â¢  Proof of neutralizing antibodies    The certificates for vaccinated, recovered and tested persons are on an equal footing, but differ in their validity period    Sources:  https://archive.vn/3dN2m [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/ZM5VV [Coronavirus - Current Measures]

At work [please note these guidelines include some which will be introduced from 1 November onwards]   â¢  Employees, owners and operators are only allowed to enter workplaces where physical contact with other people cannot be ruled out if they have a 3G certificate. Contacts within the meaning of the first sentence do not include a maximum of two physical contacts per day that take place outdoors and each do not last longer than 15 minutes.   â¢  Up to and including November 14th, employees, owners and operators who do not provide a 3G certificate are required to wear an FFP2 mask. From November 15th, a workplace may only be entered with valid 3G proof without exception.   â¢  The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.   â¢  With regard to the wearing of a mask and the submission of evidence of a low epidemiological risk, stricter regulations that go beyond this ordinance can be provided in justified cases.    Customer areas   â¢  An FFP2 mask must be worn in everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and in grocery stores (including sales outlets of food producers and petrol stations with affiliated sales outlets for groceries).    â¢  When entering and driving in other customer areas as well as the connecting structures of structurally connected operating facilities (e.g. shopping centers, market halls), customers who do not provide 3G proof must wear an FFP2 mask.   â¢  The operator of business premises for the use of body-friendly services is only allowed to let customers in if they can present a 3G certificate. The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    Leisure, sport and culture    *Leisure*  Leisure facilities are businesses and facilities that serve entertainment, amusement or recreation. Leisure facilities are in particular:    â¢  Fairgrounds, amusement and amusement parks   â¢  Baths   â¢  Dance schools   â¢  Betting offices, slot machines, amusement arcades and casinos   â¢  Show mines   â¢  Facilities for the practice of prostitution   â¢  Indoor playgrounds   â¢  Paintball systems   â¢  Museum railways   â¢  Animal parks, zoos and botanical gardens    The following applies in this area:   â¢  Customers must show a 3G certificate, which must be kept available for the duration of their stay.   â¢  Every leisure company must create a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer.    *Culture*  In museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives, people who do not provide 3G proof must wear an FFP2 mask.  For cultural institutions in which mainly get-togethers take place, such as theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, a 3G certificate, a COVID-19 officer and a prevention concept are required.    *Sports*  The 3G rule applies to sports facilities. The proof must be kept ready for the duration of the stay.   Operators of non-public sports facilities must create a Covid-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.    Top athletes:  When top athletes practice sports, the responsible doctor must develop a COVID-19 prevention concept and monitor compliance with it on an ongoing basis.  Top athletes have to show a 3G certificate for training and competitions if physical contact with other people cannot be ruled out.  If a SARS-CoV-2 infection becomes known to an athlete, supervisor or trainer, all athletes, supervisors and trainers must undergo a molecular biological test or an antigen test for the presence of a SARS-CoV- 2 to undergo infection.    Gastronomy and accommodation    *Gastronomy*  When visiting a restaurant, the following rules must be observed:   â¢  3-G rule in catering establishments.   â¢  2.5G proof for establishments in the hospitality industry in which an increased mix and interaction of customers is to be expected, such as discos, clubs, aprÃ¨s-ski bars and dance halls in particular.    The operators of catering establishments must also ensure the following:   â¢  Self-service buffets can be operated subject to hygiene requirements.   â¢  Every catering business must create a prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.   â¢  Mandatory collection of customer data.   â¢  The 3-G rule does not apply to the pick-up of food and drinks, as well as snack bars and catering stands. Customers have to wear a mask in closed rooms.    *Night gastronomy*  Access to night-time catering, establishments in the hospitality industry in which an increased mix and interaction of customers is to be expected, such as discotheques, clubs, aprÃ¨s-ski bars and dance halls, is for vaccinated and convalescent people, as well as people with current negative PCR- Test result (max. 72 hours old) possible (2.5G proof).    *Accommodation*  The accommodation establishments are allowed to reopen under Covid conditions. To do this, the operators must: draw up a COVID-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.   â¢  The 3G rule applies when entering for the first time. If the validity expires during the stay, a new proof must be provided.   â¢  For the use of the culinary offer in hotels and accommodation establishments, the regulations of the catering trade apply. The 3G rule must be observed for the use of gastronomy, wellness and fitness offers.   â¢  Mandatory collection of customer data.   â¢  Supervised camping or caravan sites, shelters and cabin ships are also considered to be accommodation facilities.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/vgVms - Nationwide Measures  https://archive.vn/nmP8T - Coronavirus - Current Measures

New regulations in the workplace from 01.11:  â¢	3-G proof at the workplace if contact with other people cannot be ruled out there  o	With 3-G proof, release from the mask requirement  o	Transition period up to and including November 14th: without 3-G proof, FFP2 masks are mandatory  â¢	3-G obligation for top athletes: inside  â¢	Increased test intensity for unvaccinated and unrecovered employees: inside the health and care sector  â¢	Access to workplaces in the health and care sector only with 3-G proof  â¢	Mouth and nose protection is mandatory in addition to the 3-G certificate in old people's and nursing homes as well as in hospitals  â¢	Furthermore, FFP2 mask compulsory for customers and visitors in places to cover necessary basic needs (e.g. supermarkets, pharmacies, public transport), in care and health facilities in addition to 3G  â¢	3-G proof or FFP2 mask in other customer areas (e.g. non-essential retail, travel agencies, museums)  â¢	Furthermore, no mask requirement in 3-G settings (e.g. gastronomy, accommodation providers, theaters, hairdressers, events)    Sources:  https://archive.vn/nmP8T [Coronavirus - Current Measures]  https://archive.vn/SXpx3 [FAQ]  https://web.archive.org/web/20211101214354/https://www.bma.gv.at/Services/News/Coronavirus/FAQ-3-G-am-Arbeitsplatz.html [FAQ]

Current measures from November 8, 2021    3-G becomes 2-G: Wherever 3-G was previously in effect, only vaccinated and recovered people have access. This applies to:  â¢	body-hugging services,  â¢	Gastronomy, night gastronomy, Christmas markets, hotels and similar settings,  â¢	the cultural sector (theaters, cinemas and operas, but not museums),  â¢	Sports and leisure facilities  â¢	Visits to hospitals and old people's and nursing homes, with the exception of visits as part of palliative and hospice support or support during childbirth. An FFP 2 mask must also be worn in closed rooms .  Transition period until December 6th, 2021: Until then, access is also possible with a first vaccination and an additional PCR test.     Workplace : In principle, the 3-G rule applies; stricter rules are prescribed in particularly sensitive areas.  â¢	Employees in night catering and at major events (from 250 participants) who have neither been vaccinated nor recovered can also show a valid PCR test. However, only people who have been tested for PCR must also wear an FFP 2 mask.  â¢	The same rule applies to employees in health and care facilities. So only tested people have to wear an FFP 2 mask. In addition, mouth and nose protection is required in this setting for vaccinated and convalescent people.  â¢	Antibody tests are no longer valid as G detection.    A 2.5 G rule (vaccinated, recovered or PCR-tested) has already been in effect for employees in the following areas since November 8: Night restaurants, discos, aprÃ¨s-ski, elderly, care and residential facilities for the disabled, in hospitals, in mobile care and support and at events with over 250 participants.    There is a transition period up to and including November 14th. During the period, people who cannot produce a 3-G certificate are required to wear an FFP2 mask for the entire working time    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112143651/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html  https://archive.vn/dA29v  https://archive.vn/hWG2m  https://archive.vn/wxXb4  https://archive.vn/a3vmo

In Vienna  For the federal state of Vienna, the following additional, stricter measures apply from November 12th (until December 12th) :    Job  For all places of professional activity in Vienna, in addition to the nationwide measures, a 2.5G proof (PCR test max. 48 hours old) applies.    Gastronomy   For customers, the 2G regulation applies to snack and restaurant stands.    Source; https://archive.vn/Dj4ZE [Vienna measurements]

At work (nationwide guidelines)  â¢	Employees, owners and operators are only allowed to enter workplaces where physical contact with other people cannot be ruled out if they have a 3G certificate. Contacts within the meaning of the first sentence do not include a maximum of two physical contacts per day that take place outdoors and each do not last longer than 15 minutes.  â¢	The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.  â¢	With regard to the wearing of a mask and the submission of evidence of a low epidemiological risk, stricter regulations that go beyond this ordinance can be provided in justified cases.  â¢	A 2G rule generally applies to employees of night-time catering establishments and major events (from 250 participants) at the workplace. Alternatively, a valid PCR test can also be presented, in which case an FFP2 mask must also be worn.  â¢	Workplaces in the health and care sector may only be entered with a 2G certificate. In retirement and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled as well as in hospitals and health resorts and other places where health services are provided, in addition to the 2G proof, it is also compulsory to wear mouth and nose protection in closed rooms. Alternatively, a valid PCR test can also be presented; an FFP2 mask must also be worn here.    Customer areas  â¢	Customers may only enter customer areas of business premises for the purpose of purchasing goods or using services if they have 2G evidence (exceptions to the point of exit regulation or the 5th COVID-19 Protective Measures Ordinance ).  â¢	When entering and driving in the customer area of business premises, as well as the connecting structures of structurally connected business premises (e.g. shopping centers, market halls), customers must wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms.  â¢	The operator of business premises for the use of body-friendly services is only allowed to let customers in if they can present proof of 2G. The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    In Vienna  â¢	For all places of professional activity in Vienna, in addition to the nationwide measures, a 2.5G proof (PCR test max. 48 hours old) applies.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/WYxDd#selection-1977.0-2045.91 [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/FID4b {Vienna]

At work  â¢	Employees, owners and operators are only allowed to enter workplaces where physical contact with other people cannot be ruled out if they have a 3G certificate. Contacts within the meaning of the first sentence do not include a maximum of two physical contacts per day that take place outdoors and each do not last longer than 15 minutes.  â¢	The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.  â¢	With regard to the wearing of a mask and the submission of evidence of a low epidemiological risk, stricter regulations that go beyond this ordinance can be provided in justified cases.  â¢	For employees of night-time catering establishments and of major events (from 250 participants: inside) a 2G rule generally applies at the workplace. Alternatively, a valid PCR test can also be presented, in which case an FFP2 mask must also be worn. (Exception: operators: inside, employees may, as an exception, admit an authorized body with a negative antigen test, provided that no negative PCR test can be presented due to lack of availability or an evaluation that is not timely. This also applies accordingly to the operators: Inside).  â¢	Workplaces in the health and care sector may only be entered with a 2G certificate. In old people's and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled as well as in hospitals and spa facilities and other places where health services are provided, in addition to the 2G proof, it is also mandatory to wear mouth and nose protection in closed rooms. Alternatively, a valid PCR test can also be presented; an FFP2 mask must also be worn here. (Exception: operators: inside, employees may, as an exception, admit an authorized body with a negative antigen test, provided that no negative PCR test can be presented due to lack of availability or an evaluation that is not timely. This also applies accordingly to the operators: Inside).    Sources:  https://archive.vn/kqgPP [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/EYqru [Coronavirus - Current Measures]

Exit regulation  For people who do not have 2G proof, leaving their own private living area (including residential units in accommodation establishments as well as in old people's, nursing and handicapped homes) and staying outside their own private living area is only permitted for the following purposes:  1.	Avoidance of an immediate danger to life, limb and property.  2.	Care of and assistance for people in need of support as well as exercise of family rights and fulfilment of family duties.  3.	Covering the basic needs of daily life.  4.	professional and educational purposes.  5.	Staying outdoors alone, with people from the common household, life partners who do not live in the common household, individual closest relatives (parents, children and siblings), individual important caregivers.  6.	to pursue administrative or judicial processes that cannot be postponed.  7.	to participate in elections provided by law and to use the instruments of direct democracy provided by law.  8.	for the purpose of entering customer areas of certain business premises such as pharmacies, grocery stores, drugstores, health and care services, petrol stations, banks, postal service providers, car and bicycle workshops, picking up pre-ordered meals, ..).    Source:  https://archive.vn/WYxDd [Nationwide measures]

Clearance and mouth and nose protection - Nationwide Measures  There is no minimum distance of one meter from other people. In all places where the 3-G rule applies, there is no mask requirement. This also applies to employees in those areas in which a 3-G certificate is intended.    In everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and grocery stores, an FFP2 mask must be worn again instead of the previous MNS wearing obligation.    In addition, the wearing of an FFP2 mask in trade and cultural institutions becomes an obligation for unvaccinated people. Wearing an FFP2 mask is recommended for people who have been vaccinated.    Children up to the age of 6 do not have to wear an FFP2 mask or an MNS. Children from the age of 6 up to the age of 14 are also allowed to wear an MNS. Pregnant women are also allowed to wear an MNS.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/3dN2m [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/ZM5VV [Coronavirus - Current Measures]

Clearance and mouth and nose protection - Nationwide Measures     â¢  An FFP2 mask must be worn when entering public places in closed rooms.   â¢  There is no minimum distance of one meter from other people. In all places where the 3G rule applies, there is no mask requirement.   â¢  In addition, wearing an FFP2 mask in retail and cultural institutions will become an obligation for people without a 3G certificate. Wearing an FFP2 mask is recommended for people who have been vaccinated.   â¢  Children up to the age of 6 do not have to wear an FFP2 mask or an MNS. Children from the age of 6 up to the age of 14 are also allowed to wear an MNS. Pregnant women are also allowed to wear an MNS.    Mask requirement - Upper Austria   â¢  In Upper Austria, customers are obliged to wear the FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard when entering, driving on and lingering in customer areas of production facilities in closed rooms as well as in connecting structures of structurally connected production facilities (e.g. shopping centers, market halls).   â¢  This obligation also applies to visitors to museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls as well as libraries, libraries and archives.    Measures for the entire state of Salzburg   From October 18, 2021, additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19:   â¢  In addition to the FFP2 mask requirement in public pharmacies, food retailers, banks, and post offices, there is still an FFP2 mask requirement without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard  for all customers in the  customer areas of business premises in closed rooms and in connecting structures that are structurally connected Business premises (e.g. shopping centers, market halls).   â¢  The FFP2 mask requirement also applies to body-hugging services and to all cultural institutions.   â¢  Employees in retail, body-friendly services and cultural institutions are exempt from this.    Mask requirement for Vienna  In Vienna, the mask requirement applies in museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives, theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, as well as institutions for religious practice.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/vgVms [Nationwide Measures]  https://archive.vn/nmP8T#selection-1007.13-1007.43 [Current Measures]  https://archive.vn/fr3PC#selection-821.41-833.16 [Upper Austria Mask requirement]  https://archive.vn/R0LMb [Salzburg]   https://archive.vn/Fs4aL [Vienna}

Clearance and mouth and nose protection  A mask (FFP2 mask without exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard) must be worn wherever 2G verification is not required. In addition to public transport and essential trade, this also applies to non-essential trade and to customer areas, museums and libraries.    Children up to the age of 6 do not have to wear an FFP2 mask or an MNS. Children from the age of 6 up to the age of 14 are also allowed to wear an MNS. Pregnant women are also allowed to wear an MNS.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112143651/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html  https://archive.vn/dA29v

Travellers can now visit Azerbaijan under the following conditions:  submission of an official document issued by the relevant country (COVID passport) on complete vaccination or recovery from COVID-19 for passengers over 18 years of age and a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before the flight  submission of a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before the flight for passengers aged from 1 to 18 years.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211106152927/https://azerbaijan.travel/covid-19-en

Quote: "Citizens and legal residents of several countries, including Austria, Bahrain, Belgium, Canada, China, Croatia, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Qatar, Russia, Serbia, Singapore, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the UAE, the UK, and the US are allowed to travel to Azerbaijan by air without the previously required special permission provided they meet the following conditions:    All passengers over the age of 18 years must possess official documentation (i.e., COVID Passport) issued by the relevant country demonstrating that they have either been fully vaccinated against or have recovered from COVID-19, in addition to a negative result from a PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to their flight.    All passengers between the ages of 1-18 years must possess a negative result from a PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to their flight.    Authorities plan to perform periodic assessments and gradually ease entry restrictions for travelers from other locations. Returning Azerbaijani nationals require only a negative result from a PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to their flight to enter the country. For a full list of countries approved for travel and further details on requirements for entering Azerbaijan, click here.    Land and maritime borders remain closed. The only option for entry and exit is via air on a limited number of commercial and charter flights operating to and from selected destinations. "  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20211116005100/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/540751/azerbaijan-government-extends-special-quarantine-regime-through-jan-1-update-39

Visits to Mall-type shopping centers, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 sq m, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions may be made for shops offering mainly foodstuffs, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices.  In all markets, marketplaces, bazaars and open-air exhibitions workers are required to wear a face mask.  Employers and recruitment bodies to organize the work process of employees in remote form (teleworking/home work), where possible, allowing the present work of a maximum of 50% of staff.  Valid through to November 30th 2021    http://web.archive.org/web/20211119164309/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 1 September to 30 November 2021.  Temporary anti-epidemic measures for arrivals, according to the color zones:    Green zone - allowed on the territory of the country upon presentation of a valid EU digital COVID certificate for vaccination, disease or testing or a similar document containing the same data as the EU digital COVID certificate. In the absence of a valid EU digital COVID certificate or a similar document the person shall be quarantined for 10 days at the home or other accommodation where he has indicated that he will reside, with a prescription issued by the director of the respective regional health inspection or a deputy director authorized by him. The quarantined person may, by the end of the day following his arrival in the country, carry out a polymerase chain reaction test to detect COVID-19 or a rapid antigen test. In the event of a negative result of the examination, the quarantine of the person shall be considered terminated from the day following the registration of the result in the National Information System for Combating COVID-19.    Orange zone  - allowed on the territory of the country only upon presentation of a valid EU digital COVID certificate for vaccination, disease or testing or a similar document containing the same data as the EU digital COVID certificate. Bulgarian citizens and persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and members of their families who do not present a document shall be quarantined for a period of 10 days. The quarantined person may, by the end of the day following his arrival in the country, carry out a polymerase chain reaction test to detect COVID-19 or a rapid antigen test as specified in. The person is considered suspended from the day following the registration of the result in the National Information System for Combating COVID-19. Teaching during the COVID-19 pandemic can be done in several ways. The opening of schools at full capacity carries  the greatest risk of COVID-19 transmission and the emergence of hotspots, as well as widespread transmission in the  community. This risk can be reduced by implementing hygienic and epidemiological measures,    however, due to limited capacity, as well as problems in controlling the behavior of children and adolescents,  this is a challenge.    Educate staff, parents, and students about COVID-19, including symptoms, complications, how it is  transmitted, and how to prevent transmission. Get information about COVID-19 through reputable  sources such as health institutions, the World Health Organization (WHO), UNICEF. Point out false  information / myths that can circulate orally or online.  Educate all staff and students, as well as parents as much as possible, on measures to prevent the spread of  COVID-19, as well as their importance.  Update or develop school emergency plans. These plans must include responsible  persons, activities to be taken in case any of the students, staff or their  the householder becomes ill, with suspected COVID-19; as well as a specific room or area for  isolating the patient, identification of close contacts. The plan should include contact with the  local competent health institution, to whom school staff should contact in the above case, as  well as with parents.  Regardless of how classes begin, plan teaching models for students who must be in selfisolation, as well as for parents and students who belong to vulnerable groups (chronic  diseases).  Plan mental support programs and take care of the mental health of staff and students during a  pandemic.  Basic principles of prevention  Basic principles: wearing masks for students (children aged 6 to 11 should wear a mask outside  the classroom, not necessarily during classes; while older children should wear a mask during  classes), wearing masks for teaching and other staff, maintenance adequate physical distances,  maintaining hand hygiene.  Vaccination against COVID-19 teaching staff and students depending on the recommended  age for vaccination, as well as their household members, are key strategies to help schools  function at full capacity.  Students, teachers and other staff should stay home if they or any of their household  members have COVID-19-related symptoms (main symptoms are fever, cough, loss of  sense of smell / taste, malaise; other symptoms: pain, headache, conjunctivitis, diarrhea,  skin rash).  Students, teachers and other staff should stay home if they are positive for COVID-19 or in  isolation. Stay home even if they have recently been in contact with a person with COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120191619/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/preporuke-covid-19/

Activities to be provided to all employees in all work environments to prevent the  transmission of COVID-19:  - Vaccination against COVID-19 employees, as well as their household members,  is a key strategy to help them function at full capacity.  - Ensure that routine cleaning and disinfection are carried out at your workplace.  Clean and disinfect traffic areas and points of contact in buildings several times a  day, such as door handles, faucets in toilets and kitchens, power switches, buttons  in elevators, and reception desks. and other contact surfaces used by a large  number of persons.  - Clean the surfaces with soap and water or detergent, after which the surfaces should  be disinfected. Sodium hypochlorite products are recommended (according to the  manufacturer's instructions), alternatively 70-90% alcohol can be used to disinfect  surfaces. Spraying surfaces alone is not enough, and can be and can potentially cause  harmful consequences.  1  Translated from Bosnian to English - www.onlinedoctranslator.com  - Meeting rooms, trainings and other areas where a large number of people gather should be  cleaned after each meeting.  - Put hand sanitizers in visible places everywhere in workplaces, especially in  public places where people have fewer opportunities to wash their hands  regularly. Ensure that these funds are regularly updated.  - For hand washing in toilets, provide warm running water and soap, as well as  disposable paper towels.  - Promote proper and regular hand washing by employees, partners and clients.    Develop a plan for a comprehensive ongoing work process in case of the spread  of COVID-19 in the local community where your business organization /  institution operates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120191619/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/preporuke-covid-19/

Crowds should be prevented. Appropriate measures must be taken to ensure physical distance  between persons during the event, and to prevent direct close contact between persons.  This is achieved:  by reducing the number of participants, increasing the  capacity for passenger transport,  creating a planned schedule of arrival and departure of visitors,  by minimizing the possibility of grouping people at key points (toilets, places with  food).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120191619/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/preporuke-covid-19/

Limit the number of guests to the smallest possible number, and in accordance with the currently valid orders of  the competent crisis headquarters - up to 50 people indoors. The presence of only celebrants and necessary  guests (eg high school graduates) and the necessary staff is recommended, with as few guests as possible (eg  family members). The presence of persons from abroad is not recommended, as well as persons older than 65  years.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120191619/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/preporuke-covid-19/

Inform passengers about the importance of maintaining a physical distance of at least one meter from each  other.  The number and arrangement of passengers by seats must be such as to allow the prescribed distance  (1-2 m, or one empty seat) between them. Limit the capacity to the seats so that one person sits in a  row, in such a way that they sit alternately in the left and right seats. Mark unused places with a tape or  warning sign. We recommend that you do not allow standing and holding the handles while driving,  except when entering and exiting the vehicle.  All passengers must have protective masks, in accordance with previous orders.  An increased presence of auditors in vehicles is recommended. In public urban transport in particular, to ensure  compliance with the measures by passengers and the permitted number of passengers per vehicle.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120191619/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/preporuke-covid-19/

U.S. citizens wishing to enter BiH must have one of the following: a negative COVID-19 test (PCR or antigen) not older than 48 hours if coming from Europe and not older than 72 hours if arriving from other countries (including the United States); or a COVID-19 vaccination certificate showing full vaccination completed 10 days prior to arrival; or a doctorâs certificate of COVID-19 recovery in the period 10 to 180 days prior to arrival.  Children until the age of seven, accompanied by a parent who meets the above conditions may enter without a COVID-19 test or certificate.  Foreign nationals who are permanently or temporarily resident in BiH may enter without a COVID-19 test or certificate if returning from Croatia, Montenegro or Serbia with stays in those countries for less than 48 hours.  Citizens of Croatia, Montenegro or Serbia may enter without a COVID-19 test or certificate when coming directly from those countries.  The BiH Border Police website has detailed information on entry and exit requirements and exceptions. For the most up-to-date information, visit their website or contact them directly by calling their Operations Center at +387 33 755 300.    Requirements and restrictions may change without advance notice.  Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? No.  See above.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? No  Nations bordering BiH also maintain border restrictions. For questions regarding those, please visit the following websites:    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120194232/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in BiH? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  A list of clinics known to provide COVID-19 testing in BiH can be found on our website here  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your cantonâs health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120194232/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Depending on level of coronavirus in country travellers are arriving from, different entry rules apply.  All arrivals must fill out an electronic arrival form before departing for the Czech Republic. They must also produce a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before departure. Travelers from green or orange countries can opt to take an antigen test taken no more than 48 hours before departure or within five days of arrival. Travelers from red and dark red countries must take a second COVID-19 test no earlier than five days after arrival and remain in self-isolation until the results return. A full list of country classifications is available here.    Permitted travelers who can present a certificate of vaccination or recovery from COVID-19 are exempt from testing and isolation requirements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211115141505/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/531791/czech-republic-authorities-enforcing-international-covid-19-risk-classifications-and-domestic-measures-as-of-oct-6-update-51  https://web.archive.org/web/20211115151350/https://covid.gov.cz/en/measures/travelling-abroad/arriving-countries-high-risk-covid-19-transmission  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102163326/https://koronavirus.mzcr.cz/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/Protective-Measure-regarding-the-entry-of-persons-on-the-territory-of-the-Czechia-from-27th-October-2021.pdf

There are new entry requirements in Denmark which came into effect on October 25.    1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents in EU/Schengen or an OECD-country*, can enter Denmark from a EU/Schengen country without testing or self-isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test before entering Denmark from an EU/Schengen country or within 24 hours after arrival  2) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents from COVID-19 risk countries*, can enter Denmark from a EU/Schengen country with testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test within 24 hours after arrival  3) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211030131742/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

Rules were updated on November 3    1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen can enter Denmark. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test before entering Denmark  or within 24 hours after arrival    2) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents from COVID-19 risk countries*, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test within 24 hours after arrival    3) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211104165021/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

In Denmark, a face mask or shield is required at the airport. People are also advised to wear a face mask or shield at test centres or when visiting the hospital. However, some groups are exempt from the required use of face mask or shield. These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves. Face masks may be removed if the wearer experience a severe discomfort, such as difficulty breathing.      https://web.archive.org/web/20211030131256/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

In Denmark, a face mask or shield is required at the airport. People are also advised to wear a face mask or shield at test centres or when visiting the hospital. However, some groups are exempt from the required use of face mask or shield. These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves. Face masks may be removed if the wearer experience a severe discomfort, such as difficulty breathing. The Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health have examined the grounds for the validity of the national telework recommendation and propose that the telework recommendation end on 15 October. However, the Department of Health and Welfare estimates recommends the extension of the telework recommendation one month onwards, until October 31. However, this is not necessary in areas that are considered low-risk in terms of Covid 19 transmission rates. In the area of ??the Hospital Districts of Southern Ostrobothnia and Central Ostrobothnia, an indoor event of up to of 100 people may be held, if:    1) there are auditoriums where no seating is provided for all participants,  or   2) there are joint singing events belonging to public events.   Other types of public events and general meetings are allowed. The organizer of the events described above may introduce a corona passport as an alternative to the existing corona restrictions, in which case the passport will allow admission to events and activities.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211115172413/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta

In Southwest Finland, indoor events is restricted to 50 people however, the event organizer may introduce a corona passport as an alternative to the restrictions, in which case the passport will allow admission to events and activities. Other types of public events and general meetings are allowed. Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211030123532/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. Those laid off temporarily and the lay-off started on or after 16 March 2020, are eligible for an unemployment benefit even if they are studying. This is a temporary change that will be effective until 31 December 2021. A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with. No change in policy, entry to France remains controlled depending on the vaccination status, reason for traveling, and country of traveler origin. Origin countries are categorised as Green/Orange/Red depending on Covid-19 prevalence, and as of 11/5 are:     - "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, Chile, comoros, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu.  - "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which there is active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.  - "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname and Turkey.    Travelers from Green list countries aged twelve years or older are not subject to the regime of compelling reasons, but are required to present:    - proof of having received all the doses prescribed for one of the vaccines approved by the European Medicines Agency  - or the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) performed less than 72 hours before departure.  - or a recovery certificate dating back more than eleven days and less than six months (this document is issued to the person who has been contaminated by Covid-19 on presentation of a positive result in an RT-PCR screening examination or an antigen test).    A reinforced regimen is in place for the United Kingdom, with a test initially required (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours for unvaccinated people.    For travelers from Orange list countries:    Unvaccinated travellers from these countries/territories must present at boarding, the negative result of a PCR test performed less than 72 hours or an antigen test (TAG) performed less than 48 hours before the flight. They may be subject to a random antigen test upon arrival.  Vaccinated travellers are not subject to the "compelling reasons" regime.  Unvaccinated travellers are subject to the regime of compelling reasons and will have to undertake self-isolation for 7 days. The list of compelling reasons is specified in thetravel and travel certificate issued by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.    For travel from Red list countries:   Unvaccinated travellers from these countries/territories:  - are subject to the regime of compelling reasons, the list of which is specified in the travel and travel certificate drawn up by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.  - must present at boarding, the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight.  - will be subject to a mandatory antigen test upon arrival.  - will be subject to a mandatory 10-day quarantine,controlled by the security forces.    Those travelers from countries that must demonstrate a "compelling reason" may be denied entry if their journey does not meet the requirements deailed at https://web.archive.org/web/20211102144014/https://www.interieur.gouv.fr/Actualites/L-actu-du-Ministere/Attestation-de-deplacement-et-de-voyage     https://web.archive.org/web/20211105173602/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

Indoor entertainment venues, restaurants, bars and cafes will only be accessible to vaccinated or recently recovered customers, with verification checks conducted at entrances through an app that scans COVID-19 certificates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211105110420/https://apnews.com/article/europe-business-health-greece-coronavirus-pandemic-9656434341e8db7aa36fd73a2cbbb50c

no policy change     At level 4 (red) of the Epidemiology Charter country incorporated the Regional Units Kavala, Imathia, Pieria and Pella , while extending a special, local, measures in Regional Units Haryana and Argolis , after re-evaluation of epidemiological data the Committee of Infectious Diseases and the National Committee for the Protection of Public Health against the Covid-19 coronavirus in the context of the epidemiological surveillance of the country by Regional Unit and Municipality on a weekly basis.    At the same time, level 3 (orange) includes the Regional Units of Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Heraklion , as well as the Municipality of Ikaria .    It is reminded that the measures in force are the following:    Traffic ban from 01:00 in the evening until 06:00 in the morning, with the exception of work and serious health reasons.  Prohibition of music around the clock in stores of health interest and entertainment.  The measures are valid from tomorrow, Friday 17 September at 06.00 until Friday 24 September at 6:00 .    It is also reminded that in these areas, as well as in the whole territory, it is forbidden to hold any form of events in exchange for any form of exchange, with the physical presence of a crowd of more than twenty (20) people in a private, non-professional space . The administrative fine in case of violation amounts from 50,000 to 200,000 euros for the lessee or concessionaire of the private, non-professional space, in which the said event took place or takes place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210919221253/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/sto-epipedo-4-toy-epidimiologikoy-harti-tis-horas-kavala-imathia-pieria-kai-pella

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus
The government of Greece imposes a curfew between 00.00 to 06.00 in the red zones.   https://web.archive.org/https://covid19.gov.gr/covid-map-en/

From 5 August, there are additional gathering restrictions in Sisimiut, Upernavik, Upernavik district and Aasiaat. A maximum of 20 persons may gather in these geographic areas, for both outdoor and indoor arrangements, events, and other public activities. Some public establishments may be required to limit access to fewer than 20 persons, depending on the size of their area. This is valid through 31 October.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211103045749/https://blog.wego.com/greenland-travel-restrictions-and-quarantine-requirements/

Persons 12 years of age and older who travel out of Nuuk or Sisimiut to another place in Greenland, and who are not fully vaccinated, must go into quarantine for 14 days upon arrival to their destination, or go into quarantine until receiving a negative test result on a PCR test taken on the 5th day after departure from Nuuk or Sisimiut, at the earliest. This is valid through 30 November 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211103045826/https://visitgreenland.com/corona-faq/#toggle-id-13-closed

If you have not been vaccinated and travel out of Nuuk or Sisimiut, you must be quarantined for five days and tested for COVID-19 when you arrive at your destination in Greenland. You must be tested on the 5th day or later after departure, and if your test is negative, you are considered not to be infected. If you do not allow yourself to be tested on the 5th day, you must stay in the same city for a minimum of 14 consecutive days prior to the trip before you can travel on to another city.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211111213824/https://corona.nun.gl/da/rejser/indenrigsrejser-i-gronland/

If you have not been vaccinated and travel out of Nuuk or Sisimiut, you must be quarantined for five days and tested for COVID-19 when you arrive at your destination in Greenland. You must be tested on the 5th day or later after departure, and if your test is negative, you are considered not to be infected. If you do not allow yourself to be tested on the 5th day, you must stay in the same city for a minimum of 14 days in a row prior to the trip before you can travel on to another city.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211111213824/https://corona.nun.gl/da/rejser/indenrigsrejser-i-gronland/

People aged 12+ who travel from Nuuk or Upernavik to another place in Greenland must, as a rule, be fully vaccinated against COVID-19. A negative PCR test is not enough. You are considered fully vaccinated against COVID-19 when you have completed a vaccination process and can document this.  If you are fully vaccinated, you can travel out of Nuuk or Upernavik without first having to present a negative coronate test.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211124000352/https://corona.nun.gl/da/rejser/indenrigsrejser-i-gronland/

Before 1 November, there was a requirement that the PCR test, taken a maximum of 72 hours before departure for Greenland, had to be carried out in a Nordic country. From 1 November, the requirement is now that the test must be performed at a hospital or health clinic, etc. in one of the Nordic countries, the EU, EFTA or the United Kingdom.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211103045826/https://visitgreenland.com/corona-faq/#toggle-id-13-closed

Only fully-vaccinated individuals or residents of Greenland can travel to Greenland. Required negative-COVID-19 test taken in the UK, nordic country, or the EU within 72 hours of travelling.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211111214222/https://corona.nun.gl/da/rejser/indrejse-til-gronland/

To travel into Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or resident in Greenland or on your way to move to Greenland. As well, you must show proof of a negative COVID PCR test from a Nordic country, the UK, or a country in the EU within the last 72 hours.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211111214222/https://corona.nun.gl/da/rejser/indrejse-til-gronland/

People are required to wear masks/facial coverings to some public spaces. This requirement on wearing a mask or visor does not include people who have reduced levels of consciousness, physical or mental impairment or anything else which might make one unable to wear a mask.       https://web.archive.org/web/20211103045826/https://visitgreenland.com/corona-faq/#toggle-id-13-closed

In Greenland, you are required to wear a bandage in the following situations:  For international and domestic flights (bandages are carried to the quarantine site / final destination) for everyone 12 years and older.  If you are infected or at risk of being infected with COVID-19 and exceptionally need to move out, e.g. because you need to be tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211111210808/https://corona.nun.gl/da/

All citizens aged 12+, including pregnant and breastfeeding women, are offered COVID-19 vaccination.  Vaccination is a free and voluntary offer. Schools and colleges are adapting to the situation on a daily basis, and in order to provide education to all students in educational institutions, a hybrid model of education has been introduced - some have continued classroom teaching and some have introduced online teaching to prevent the spread of coronavirus. The new condition is also the physical distance that everyone must adhere to, so in educational institutions it is precisely determined what the distance between the tables must be, when the masks must be worn and how long the school lesson or lecture will last. What is school without its students?    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112162611/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-skolovanju/13
No change in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211115185023/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-skolovanju/13
Recommendation exist, same as previously

In order to adapt as much as possible to the new conditions, employers are advised to organize, wherever possible, work from home or work in shifts, in order to avoid interference by workers. For the protection of one's own, but also the health of others, it is recommended that all business trips be postponed and that meetings be held online. Jobs related to the health care system also have specially prescribed measures that employees must adhere to so that the system itself is not overloaded. All recommendations for employees and employers in trade, catering facilities, measures for drivers in road freight transport or employees in the state administration, can be found here.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163018/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-poslu/46
No change in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163018/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-poslu/46
Recommendation exist, same as previously

Gatherings - measures take effect tomorrow    Today, the Headquarters passed a new Decision which regulates, ie restricts gatherings, which will take effect tomorrow , and the most important changes are:    It is forbidden to hold all public events and gatherings indoors where more than 50 people are present in one place, unless it is a public event or gathering attended only by persons with an EU digital COVID certificate , and the same is the responsibility of the civil headquarters. protection of local self-government units gave consent. (so far it referred to more than 100)  Measures are being tightened to hold all public events and gatherings indoors with more than 50 people, where, with the participation of the EU digital COVID certificate, it will be mandatory to use a medical mask or face mask and maintain the necessary physical distance . (so far this has not been mandatory for gatherings with the EU digital COVID certificate).  The measure of banning all public events and outdoor gatherings attended by more than 100 people in one place is still valid, unless it is a public event or gathering attended only by persons with an EU digital COVID certificate .  All ** public events and gatherings ** must end no later than 24.00 hours, which means that gatherings with EU digital COVID certificates for which the local headquarters has given consent for maintenance cannot last longer than 24.00 hours , nor professional artistic performances and programs, exhibitions in museum spaces and similar cultural events. * The only exceptions are cinema screenings that started before 23.00 and can end after 24.00. Also, wedding ceremonies where all those present have EU digital COVID certificates must end no later than 02.00 (so far they have not been limited in time), and additional time limits will be considered according to the epidemiological situation. *  congresses and conferences will be able to be held only if all those present have an EU digital COVID certificate , and the condition is that it is mandatory to use medical masks or face masks and to maintain physical distance.  Sports competitions will be able to be held in the presence of spectators only if everyone has EU digital COVID certificates (there is no possibility of attending up to 100 spectators with an epidemiological framework developed by the County Institute of Public Health and County Headquarters), and indoors spectators except the EU Digital COVID certification, you must also use medical masks or face masks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163612/https://www.koronavirus.hr/od-06-11-ogranicenja-za-okupljanja-a-od-15-11-covid-potvrde-u-drzavnim-i-javnim-slu%C5%BEbama-uklju%C4%8Dujuci-i-skole/992

No change in policy. There will be a change in policy regarding Covid certificates in government services, including schools, starting on 05/11/21.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211114221129/https://koronavirus.hr/od-06-11-ogranicenja-za-okupljanja-a-od-15-11-covid-potvrde-u-drzavnim-i-javnim-slu%C5%BEbama-uklju%C4%8Dujuci-i-skole/992

(so far it referred to more than 100)  Measures are being tightened to hold all public events and gatherings indoors with more than 50 people, where, with the participation of the EU digital COVID certificate, it will be mandatory to use a medical mask or face mask and maintain the necessary physical distance . (so far this has not been mandatory for gatherings with the EU digital COVID certificate).  The measure of banning all public events and outdoor gatherings attended by more than 100 people in one place is still valid, unless it is a public event or gathering attended only by persons with an EU digital COVID certificate . (so far this has not been mandatory for gatherings with the EU digital COVID certificate).  The measure of banning all public events and outdoor gatherings attended by more than 100 people in one place is still valid, unless it is a public event or gathering attended only by persons with an EU digital COVID certificate .    https://web.archive.org/web/20211117225936/https://koronavirus.hr/od-06-11-ogranicenja-za-okupljanja-a-od-15-11-covid-potvrde-u-drzavnim-i-javnim-slu%C5%BEbama-uklju%C4%8Dujuci-i-skole/992

We take increased care of hand hygiene on a daily basis, avoid touching our eyes, nose and mouth with dirty hands, and handling and direct contact should be kept to a minimum. Going out, visiting museums and entertainment in general are temporarily restricted, all in order to maximize the impact on preventing the spread of coronavirus indoors. During all events and trips, it is important to adhere to the prescribed measures and recommendations. Regarding occupational health, it is recommended to introduce work from home or shift work, in order to avoid unwanted situations as much as possible. In order to protect yourself and others, you avoid gatherings, but do not forget to help those who need help the most today, our elderly fellow citizens. It is primarily important for everyone to preserve health, because when a person is healthy - he can do a lot.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210827182507/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-svakodnevnom-zivotu/185

Passengers traveling to the Republic of Croatia from one of the EU / EEA Member States  Passengers coming directly from EU member states and / or regions, ie Schengen member states and / or regions and countries associated with the Schengen area, regardless of citizenship, will be allowed to enter the Republic of Croatia if they have a valid EU digital COVID certificate.    If the said persons transited through other countries / regions without delay during the journey to the border crossings of the Republic of Croatia, they should prove at the border crossing that they did not stay in the transit areas.    The EU digital COVID certificate is a certificate issued in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2021/953 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 June 2021 on a framework for the issuance, verification and acceptance of interoperable COVID-19 vaccination, testing and recovery certificates. COVID certificate) to facilitate free movement during the COVID-19 pandemic.       Exceptionally, passengers coming directly from the countries and / or regions of the European Union or the countries and / or regions of the Schengen area and the countries associated to the Schengen area, and do not yet have an EU digital COVID certificate, will be allowed to enter the Republic of Croatia with:     negative PCR test or  rapid antigen test - BAT  on SARS-CoV-2, where the BAT test must be from the  Common list of rapid antigen tests mutually recognized by the Member States of the European Union , published by the European Commission. When finding a  BAT  test made abroad, the test manufacturer and / or the commercial name of the test must be visible. Otherwise, the test will not be accepted as credible for entry into the Republic of Croatia. The result of the PCR test must not be older than 72 hours, and the BAT test of 48 hours from the moment of testing until the arrival at the border crossing.   confirmation not older than 365 days of receipt of two doses of vaccine used in EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm) or presentation of a certificate not older than 365 days of receipt of one dose of vaccine received in one dose (Janssen / Johnson & Johnson) if 14 days have passed since receiving that one dose;  confirmation of recovery from COVID-19 and receipt of a single dose of vaccine within eight months of the onset of the disease, provided that vaccination must be carried out less than 365 days before arrival at the border crossing;   confirmation of receipt of the first dose of Pfizer, Moderna or Gamaleya, with which it is possible to enter the Republic of Croatia in the period from 22 to 42 days from the receipt of the vaccine, or from 22 to 84 days from the first dose of AstraZeneca;  presentation of a positive PCR or  rapid antigen test,  confirming that the owner has recovered from SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which test was performed 365 days ago, and older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing or presentation of a medical certificate about the patient ;  or perform PCR testing or  rapid antigen testing - BAT  on SARS-CoV-2 immediately upon arrival in the Republic of Croatia (at its own expense), with the obligation of self-isolation until the arrival of a negative finding. In case of impossibility of testing, a measure of self-isolation is determined for a period of ten (10) days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112165703/https://www.koronavirus.hr/o-covidu/733
No change in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112165703/https://www.koronavirus.hr/o-covidu/733

Aid to preserve jobs - short-time work scheme for 2021  The aid is granted for temporary introduction of the short-time work scheme for employees in a manner that employees work full time, but shorter than the usual monthly fund of working hours, up to a maximum of 90% of working hours. At the annual level there the short-time work scheme cannot cover more than 70% of the annual fund of working hours.    The aid is calculated based on the formula whereas HRK 4,000 (approx. EUR 525) is divided by the monthly fund of hours for the month the aid is being requested for,and multiplied by the number of hours covered by the aid. The amount of aid is calculated in accordance with HZZâs Table of the financing amount based on the number and percentage of working hours available on this link. The aid can amount to up to HRK 3,600 (approx. EUR 475) per employee.    The employers have to apply for the aid each month for the following month.     The employer must pay the full monthly salary and calculate and pay the social security contributions for the whole salary (including the part covered by the aid). If the aid is granted, it will be paid for the previous month and the State will refund the contributions to the employer.    The aid may be granted only for employees that have been employed on the last day of the month preceding the month for which the aid is requested, excluding workers on notice period, teleworkers, outsourced workers, workers on annual or another leave. Also, workers covered by the aid may not work overtime nor be replaced by other workers.    The aid will be available for months from 1 January to 31 December 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211109113252/https://cms.law/en/int/expert-guides/cms-expert-guide-to-state-aid-in-the-eu-during-coronavirus-crisis/croatia

Vaccination is voluntary and free and is the fastest way to victory in the fight against COVID-19, and the key is to vaccinate the vast majority of citizens. Vaccination protects you and the people you live with or come in contact with. All vaccines registered in Croatia and the European Union effectively protect against severe forms of disease, hospitalization and death. On this page you can find more information about vaccinations and vaccines used in Croatia.  All citizens residing or residing in Croatia can be vaccinated against COVID-19. Vaccines are not intended for children under 16 or 18 years of age, and the vaccination age depends on the type of vaccine. However, due to the higher risk of developing more severe forms of COVID-19 disease, preference is given to people with chronic diseases and the elderly. These include people with respiratory, cardiovascular, malignant, kidney diseases, diabetes and immunodeficiencies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211114003829/https://www.koronavirus.hr/o-cijepljenju/329
https://web.archive.org/web/20211114003829/https://www.koronavirus.hr/o-cijepljenju/329

3. CAN I GET VACCINATED AGAINST SARS-COV-2 OUTSIDE MY RESIDENCE?  If you are not able to be vaccinated in your place of residence, or with the chosen family doctor, you can apply for vaccination via the portal cijepise.zdravlje.hr or the competent county public health institute in the place of your current residence.     4. CAN PERSONS WITH EUROPEAN HEALTH INSURANCE BE VACCINATED?  According to the instructions of the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Croatia, vaccination of persons who are insured by the Croatian Health Insurance Institute is currently underway, and therefore it is currently not possible to vaccinate persons who are not in this category.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211114221151/https://koronavirus.hr/o-covidu/892    COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Has the government of Croatia approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  Are vaccines available in Croatia for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes  Which vaccines are available in Croatia? PfizerâBioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.  According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.  If you have an OIB (Croatian Personal Identification Number) and a local health insurance plan, you may visit https://cijepise.zdravlje.hr/ to register to get vaccinated.  If you do not have a local health insurance plan, you may visit the following Croatian Institute of Public Health website for the contact details of the county public health institutes to register by phone.  Visit the FDAâs website to?learn more about FDA-approved vaccines?in the United States.  The United States Government does not plan to provide COVID-19 vaccinations to private U.S. citizens overseas. Please follow host country developments and guidelines for COVID-19 vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122084519/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
